ALLEGATION:
It was alleged Former Resident A was locked in a room for hours in a facility with
no behavior management room.
INVESTIGATION:
Former Resident A, age 14, is an abuse/neglect ward who resided in Dolores Hall from
9/29/17 – 12/9/19. She was discharged to her adoptive mother’s home and currently
receives aftercare services from Vista Maria.
On 3/10/20, I interviewed Former Resident A by phone regarding the allegation. The
interview was not private. Before the call ended, the adoptive mother notified me that
she had been listening on speaker phone.
Former Resident A said she was locked in a BMR multiple times and was left in there
for hours while staff slept. Although she resided in Dolores Hall, she said she was
sometimes secluded in the behavior management room (BMR) in Beata Hall. Commented [WD(1]:
It should be noted Former Resident A’s stay at Vista Maria spanned a 26-month time
period. I asked if she recalled any specific seclusion or the staff involved. Former
Resident A did not identify any specific incident. However, she began screaming at me
about “staff” in general calling them “idiots and liars.” She was loud, hyperverbal,
accusatory and aggressive. I had difficulty deciphering her words and understanding
her meaning. She screamed at me for 30 minutes and refused to listen to my
questions.
Former Resident A insisted that the seclusions were not justified by her behavior and
any incident reports I gathered would be falsified by “staff.” I asked her if she ever filed
a grievance or shared her concerns with the people at Vista. She said she filed several
grievances and made numerous complaints to supervisors, the unit manager, her
former DHHS worker, the police and the courts, but nothing changed.
When she finally stopped screaming, I asked her what she thought should be done at
Vista Maria. Former Resident A expressed that residents in open programs should
never be secluded even if their behaviors warrant it. She said she’s done with Vista and
never wants to talk about Vista again. “Thank you, goodbye.” I thanked her for the
information.
I requested all paperwork documenting Former Resident A’s seclusions from 9/29/17 –
12/9/19. Three incident reports dated 11/22/17, 9/22/18 and 12/9/18 were provided.
 11/22/17 – Resident A was threatening staff and inciting mayhem on the wing.
She was secluded in the BMR at Beata Hall for 20 minutes.
3

 9/22/18 – Two other residents were acting out. Resident A was secluded in
her room for 20 minutes.
 12/9/18 – Resident A was physically assaultive toward peers and staff. She
was secluded in the BMR at Beata Hall for less than 15 minutes. The time in
and time out were not documented.
APPLICABLE RULE
R 400.4160 Seclusion rooms; department approval required.
(1) Prior to establishing a seclusion room, an institution
shall obtain written approval from the departments
licensing authority and the department of licensing and
regulatory affairs, bureau of fire services.
ANALYSIS: The BMRs on Vista Maria’s campus are approved by DCWL
and the Fire Inspector. Bedrooms in some buildings are
capable of locking and can be used for seclusion if necessary.
The licensing rules do not prohibit secluding a resident from an
open program in another building’s BMR if her behavior
warrants it.
CONCLUSION: VIOLATION NOT ESTABLISHED
APPLICABLE RULE
R 400.4161 Seclusion rooms; policies and procedures.
An institution approved to use a seclusion room shall
establish and follow written policies and procedures
specifying its use. The policy shall include, at a minimum,
all of the following provisions:
(b) The room may only be used if a resident is in danger
of jeopardizing the safety and security of himself, herself,
or others.
4

ANALYSIS: On 9/22/18, an incident report indicates Resident A was
secluded in her room for 20 minutes when others were acting
out. The room may only be used if a resident is jeopardizing the
safety of herself or others. Resident A was not jeopardizing the
safety of herself or others.
CONCLUSION: VIOLATION ESTABLISHED
APPLICABLE RULE
R 400.4162 Seclusion rooms; administrative oversight.
(2) The chief administrator or chief administrator designee
shall track all instances of the use of a seclusion room, the
length of each confinement, the frequency of individual
residents confined, the reason for the confinement, and the
staff person who initiated the confinement for the purpose
of analyzing the effectiveness of the intervention for
controlling behavior in the program.
ANALYSIS: On 12/9/18, the length of Resident A’s confinement in seclusion
was not documented.
CONCLUSION: VIOLATION ESTABLISHED
CONSULTATION
The purpose of an incident report is to document the facts of one unusual incident such
as a restraint or seclusion. The precipitating event, staff involved and staff interventions
should also be included. Documenting several incidents/behaviors occurring over an
extended period of time in one incident report is not recommended.
For seclusions, the time in and out of the locked room must be documented. (Refer to
R 400.4162 Seclusion rooms, administrative oversight (2) length of confinement.)
I reviewed the agency’s Seclusion policy and Behavior Management policy which
defines Segregation for Safety. Segregation for Safety is a term coined by Vista
Maria to describe what happens when a dangerous situation develops and the staff
call out to “Clear the Area.”
Both the seclusion and behavior management policies are consistent with PA 116
and the Child Welfare Licensing Rules. However, based on the incident reports
reviewed, there seems to be confusion that a resident can be both Secluded and
Segregated for Safety at the same time. Staff are labelling both Seclusion and
5

Segregation for Safety for the same youth in the drop-down screen on incident
reports. In one incident report, a staff wrote the resident was “Secluded for Safety.”
In essence, the reason for all seclusions and segregations is for safety.
Residents can be segregated in unlocked rooms or other areas for their own
safety. However, they cannot be secluded (locked in) due to the dangerous
behaviors of others. I strongly recommend the above information be clarified to
direct care and supervisory staff in all Vista Maria programs.
IV. RECOMMENDATION:
Once an acceptable corrective action plan is submitted, I recommend this facility
continue its current licensing status.
